awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: End-to-End Support for Privacy in the Internet -of-things
awd_abstract_narration:
Interest in the Internet-of-Things (IoT) has increased tremendously over the past few years. Our homes, buildings, and even cities are starting to be instrumented with devices, sensors, and actuators that will provide new capabilities to users, help automate the mundane tasks in their lives, and ultimately to improve quality of life. However, a primary challenge to the long-term success of IoT is privacy. IoT sensors and actuators will be diverse and embedded all around us in the infrastructure, largely in shared spaces with unclear kinds of controls and feedback; further these devices and apps that use them will often be created by developers with little awareness or knowledge of privacy. This project takes a first-principles based approach towards enabling holistic privacy controls to address these concerns, developing an open source IoT stack which will include new privacy mechanisms, privacy models, and systems support for privacy notifications, allowing other researchers and practitioners to build upon them. The research results will serve as an educational resource for students, particularly those from underrepresented groups, and as course projects through new and existing courses taught by the researchers, such as Ubiquitous Personal Smart Agents, User-Focused Sensing Systems and Distributed Systems.  

The overarching goal of this proposal is to support privacy in Internet of Things deployments from an end-to-end perspective, taking an interdisciplinary approach to address fundamental issues in IoT privacy along four main thrusts: (1) conducting a series of interviews and surveys to understand user concerns about IoT privacy (e.g. type of data, granularity, purpose, and so on); (2) developing a suite of novel privacy mechanisms on top of an IoT software stack to make it easier for developers and end-users to manage privacy, including new forms of access control, a stream-based functional programming approach that makes it easier for developers to get personal data in a privacy-sensitive manner, and developer support for specifying purposes of data access and usage; (3) designing and evaluating new kinds of privacy notifications, as well as ways to inspect and offer some control over what specific sensors are doing; and (4) designing and evaluating new kinds of policies for letting administrators and end-users manage sensitive data, including proximity and temporal degradation of data. These proposed ideas will be implemented, deployed, and evaluated in an extensive IoT living lab testbed that is being deployed at the university. The work will lead to significant interdisciplinary advances at the intersection of cyber-physical systems, human-computer interaction, and usable privacy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Interest in the Internet-of-Things (IoT) has increased tremendously over the past few years as our environment is being increasingly instrumented with devices, sensors, and actuators to give new functionalities and automate tasks to improve quality of life. However, a key challenge with widespread IoT deployments is that of privacy. These privacy challenges  are not merely hypothetical. IoT devices have been compromised so that attackers can access video data from smart cameras within users homes. Various consumer studies have shown that concerns about privacy of these devices are a major hindrance from more widespread adoption. There have also been numerous high profile incidents where internal employees at companies have been able to access sensitive data from these IoT devices unfettered. 

This project took the stance that in order to design “privacy-aware” IoT systems we need to think holistically about privacy issues and controls for IoT from the ground up. We focused on developing an open source end-to-end stack for IoT with new privacy mechanisms, developed new privacy-aware programming models for IoT systems, we built new systems for privacy notifications and finally developed and tested new consumer facing user interfaces (UIs) for improving consumer awareness of these privacy factors at time of purchase of these devices. 

More concretely, our research focused on the following key thrusts and outcomes: 

  • New programming models for privacy-aware programming of IoT applications including Peekaboo [Oakland S&P 2022], TEO [MobiSys 2022] and Capture [USENIX 2022]

  • Helping developers with privacy, in the form of privacy annotations that can be added directly to source code, along with plugins for Integrated Development Environments (IDEs) that can use these annotations to aggregate and view all data flows within an app to help with auditing and proper use of APIs [Ubicomp/IMWUT 2018], generate privacy user interfaces [Ubicomp/IMWUT 2012], and generate privacy labels as required by Apple and Google app stores [Ubicomp/IMWUT 2024].   

  • Development of an IoT Privacy and Security Nutrition Label [CHI2019]. We performed a set of user studies with consumers to determine whether our label changed their risk perception and their willingness to purchase IoT devices [Oakland S&P 2021], whether they were willing to pay for devices with better security and privacy attributes [USENIX 2023]. We also studied the impact of label complexity, especially in the context of the US Cyber Trust Mark, of consumer understanding [CHI 2024]. We published several magazine articles on our research that were meant for the community at large, to help educate them [S&P Magazine 2022 and CACM 2024]. Our research on this project was presented by the PI at the U.S. White House, and also led to numerous talks and discussions with the FCC and NIST staffers and ultimately helped influence the launch of the US Cyber Trust Program. 

  • Design and Development of an end-to-end IoT stack with security and privacy as first class design goal.Our Mites stack has been deployed in a real office building over 100,000 sq-ft, with over 300 sensors installed and deployed in offices and common spaces, forming the first of its kind IoT testbed, with numerous novel privacy features [Ubicomp/IMWUT 2023, Won a Distinguished Paper Award]. 

  • Developed a new framework to explore the privacy versus utility tradeoff for Human Activity Recognition (HAR) tasks using audio-based IoT devices. We also implemented a novel, edge speech filter to remove likely human speech content to mitigate privacy risks called Kirigami [Ubicomp/IMWUT 2024]. 

  • Results from different user studies around the privacy issues with IoT devices and the different types of privacy protective behaviors they undertake to preserve their privacy [CHI 2022]. Development of a new privacy-aware negotiation framework for incidental visitors in a smart home with IoT sensors [ThingPoll, CHI 2024].
